reason: This PR is no longer following the correct head in my fork.  Will re-issue.
description:
This PR adds a frontend to allow for nearly all data produced by yt to be saved as a reloadable dataset.  This includes:

* geometric data containers (sphere, region, disk, all_data, etc)
* grid data containers (covering_grid, arbitrary_grid, fixed_resolution_buffer)
* spatial plots (projections, slices)
* profiles
* generic array data

In the case of projections, slices, and profiles, the reloaded datasets can be given to ``ProjectionPlot``, ``SlicePlot``, ``ProfilePlot``, and ``PhasePlot`` to regenerate images.

[This notebook](http://nbviewer.ipython.org/url/www.roe.ac.uk/~brs/notebooks/ytdata.ipynb) gives examples of all of the above functionality.

This PR is ready for review.  All functionality is complete and should have sufficient docstrings.  The remaining items are narrative docs and tests.

Update 1: tests have been added.  Only narrative docs have yet to be completed.

Update 2: docs are done.  This is ready to be reviewed in full.

Update 3: last failing test is running the single_dataset_light_ray.py recipe.  I think this might just be because the recipe was updated.
title: Adding ytdata frontend

@brittonsmith : I really like this PR so far, as I think saving/loading data objects and even YTArrays will be really useful for many users and for saving interim steps in big analyses.  

One thought: rather than making the `to_yt_dataset()` function, why not just make a series of `save()` methods that hang off of the relevant data classes and YTArray class.  That way, one could use this functionality as:

```
#!python


import yt
ds = yt.load(filename)
ad = ds.all_data()
ad.save('all data from filename.h5')
yt_array = ad['density']
yt_array.save('density of all data from filename.h5')
ad = yt.load('all data from filename.h5')
yt_array = yt.load('density of all data from filename.h5')
```


That seems more intuitive to me, but perhaps there are reasons not to do it this way?  Either way, exciting stuff!  Thanks for working on this!
content.html:
Britton Smith : I really like this PR so far, as I think saving/loading data objects and even YTArrays will be really useful for many users and for saving interim steps in big analyses.

One thought: rather than making the to_yt_dataset() function, why not just make a series of save() methods that hang off of the relevant data classes and YTArray class. That way, one could use this functionality as:

import yt
ds = yt.load(filename)
ad = ds.all_data()
ad.save('all data from filename.h5')
yt_array = ad['density']
yt_array.save('density of all data from filename.h5')
ad = yt.load('all data from filename.h5')
yt_array = yt.load('density of all data from filename.h5')

That seems more intuitive to me, but perhaps there are reasons not to do it this way? Either way, exciting stuff! Thanks for working on this!

content.raw:
For the specific example of YTArray, you can already save and load them to hdf5, just not using the exact API you've proposed here.

I worry a bit about `yt.load` becoming *too* magic and thus unmaintainable. In particular, I'm not sure that `yt.load` returning anything besides a `Dataset` is a good idea.
content.html:
For the specific example of YTArray, you can already save and load them to hdf5, just not using the exact API you've proposed here.

I worry a bit about yt.load becoming too magic and thus unmaintainable. In particular, I'm not sure that yt.load returning anything besides a Dataset is a good idea.

content.raw: @ngoldbaum I understand your caution, but what is it that you're concerned with specifically?  Right now we already have HaloCatalog objects loadable using the `yt.load()` function, and this is just generalizing that to other data objects.  What would be your preferred method for doing this?  Adding an additional `load_data_object()` function? My fear with that is that we could quickly degenerate into having several format-specific or object-specific `load()` functions.
content.html: Nathan Goldbaum I understand your caution, but what is it that you're concerned with specifically? Right now we already have HaloCatalog objects loadable using the yt.load() function, and this is just generalizing that to other data objects. What would be your preferred method for doing this? Adding an additional load_data_object() function? My fear with that is that we could quickly degenerate into having several format-specific or object-specific load() functions.

content.raw:
Well, the way this PR currently works load() would just return `Dataset` objects.

I don't think having `yt.load()` being able to load a YTArray makes any sense, especially when we already have ways to do that elsewhere (`YTArray.from_hdf5()`, specifically).
content.html:
Well, the way this PR currently works load() would just return Dataset objects.

I don't think having yt.load() being able to load a YTArray makes any sense, especially when we already have ways to do that elsewhere (YTArray.from_hdf5(), specifically).

content.raw: This PR includes a function called `to_yt_dataset()` which saves YTArrays in addition to other data objects.  It talks about "reloading" them, although I'm not sure @brittonsmith has implemented that.  I am guessing he meant to do it with the `load()` function, as the other data objects are loaded.  But that's why we're discussing this.  For instance, I wasn't even aware of the `YTArray.from_hdf5()` functionality for saving and loading `YTArrays`.  I personally like the idea of just using `save()` and `yt.load()` with all manner of objects, as I find it to be the most intuitive, but I may be in the minority here.
content.html: This PR includes a function called to_yt_dataset() which saves YTArrays in addition to other data objects. It talks about "reloading" them, although I'm not sure Britton Smith has implemented that. I am guessing he meant to do it with the load() function, as the other data objects are loaded. But that's why we're discussing this. For instance, I wasn't even aware of the YTArray.from_hdf5() functionality for saving and loading YTArrays. I personally like the idea of just using save() and yt.load() with all manner of objects, as I find it to be the most intuitive, but I may be in the minority here.

content.raw: This is the function I'm referencing.

This is probably a discussion that should happen on the mailing list.

I'm strongly -1 to making yt.load() more magic than it already is...
content.html:
This is probably a discussion that should happen on the mailing list.

I'm strongly -1 to making yt.load() more magic than it already is...

content.raw: I'm also of the opinion that ``yt.load`` should return a ``Dataset`` object.  When something is loadable as a dataset, it enables all of yt's great functionality, like geometric data selection, projections, slices, profiles, etc.  What I'm hoping is that you won't ever read in a YTArray by itself, but that it will always contain the appropriate metadata to allow it to be treated as a full-fledged dataset.
content.html: I'm also of the opinion that yt.load should return a Dataset object. When something is loadable as a dataset, it enables all of yt's great functionality, like geometric data selection, projections, slices, profiles, etc. What I'm hoping is that you won't ever read in a YTArray by itself, but that it will always contain the appropriate metadata to allow it to be treated as a full-fledged dataset.

content.raw: Agreed, only `Dataset` objects and `DatasetSeries` objects back from `load`.
content.html: Agreed, only Dataset objects and DatasetSeries objects back from load.

content.raw: OK, I'm in favor of this.  Just wanted to clarify.
content.html: OK, I'm in favor of this. Just wanted to clarify.

content.raw: Would you be ok with making a YTEP for this functionality? Having a high-level document describing what your goals for this are would help us to understand where you're going with this and where the wins are.
content.html: Would you be ok with making a YTEP for this functionality? Having a high-level document describing what your goals for this are would help us to understand where you're going with this and where the wins are.

Yes, I'll do this.

Haven't looked at the whole PR closely, but just a thought based on looking at the pastebinned examples in the PR description: I find the name of this method confusing. It seems to create a new on-disk hdf5 file, which yt is then able to load using the `yt.load()` function.  That's fine, but I think it makes more sense to call this something like `save_to_hdf5` or something similar.  To me, `to_dataset` sounds like it should return a `Dataset` instance and not write anything to disk.
content.html: Haven't looked at the whole PR closely, but just a thought based on looking at the pastebinned examples in the PR description: I find the name of this method confusing. It seems to create a new on-disk hdf5 file, which yt is then able to load using the yt.load() function. That's fine, but I think it makes more sense to call this something like save_to_hdf5 or something similar. To me, to_dataset sounds like it should return a Dataset instance and not write anything to disk.

content.raw: Or the `save()` method I described in another comment.  That seems to be the most intuitive to me anyway.
content.html: Or the save() method I described in another comment. That seems to be the most intuitive to me anyway.
